bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, December 20, 1875

div1.p: Reed learns of the death of Emilie Lawrence's nephew. He meditates on Christian duty and on life's purpose for him.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, December 20, 1875
div1.p:
Your letter
of the 16th inst. is just to hand-
I had hoped & prayed that when
your next letter came, it would
bring me the glad news that
your little nephew had been
spared, & restored to the
love of his parents & friends.
Alas! while I prayed that his
life might be prolonged to
many years of usefulness,
he had already departed for
a better and brighter home-
Ah! well may we exclaim;
“the bitter realities of life”!
A little, tender bud, cut off
ere it bloomed! A little child
removed from earth, but thank God, a little
cherub added to Heaven! I am rejoiced to
see, my darling, that you accept his death in with the
spirit of a Christian- 'Tis hard to give him up;
Oh! who can fathom the mother's grief for the
loss of a darling boy!, but after all, my sweet
Emilie, we should not forget that, by his early
departure from life, he has escaped so many
trials; so many disappointments, so many hours
of pain of body & mind. Ah! happy & blessed
little angel to have reached Home, ere
the storm arose, and while yet the birds
were carroling sweetly! Little pilgrim of
a few days, what sad, sad hours have you
escaped! God removed you ere you had ex-
perienced the cruel buffetings of this world,
and while yet thy heart knew not evil!
And for this, ought we not rather to bless his
Holy Name, than yield to unavailing grief?
Ah! my sweet E., when I see the little lambs
hastening Home, I would not call them
back, for though I have scarcely begun
life, yet I have known what sorrow is,
and felt the weight of care! Do not think,
my sweet, that I shrink from meeting life's real-
ities- No, No! that would display a want of courage
and a want of faith- Nor that I would not
wish to live many years yet! It may be that God,
in his all-wise Providence, has some wise
purpose for me, humble that I am, to fulfil, &
shall I shrink from it? We are but clay in
the potter's hands, my precious, & our duty is
to so conduct ourselfves that we may become
bright & shining lamps in this world & the next!
In conclusion, my own love, let me offer your the heart-
felt sympathy of your dearest & best friend; and
to your sister, in her bereavement, what can
I say? Naught, but that God will grant her
the Christian fortitude to bear the loss of her
darling boy, & that, in His Infinite Wisdom,
He will, at last, restore to him to her embrace!
